item.text: Documentation supports the need for an expedited procedure due to:

valueCoding.code: Acute injury that places beneficiary at risk for permanent damage.
valueCoding.display: Acute injury that places beneficiary at risk for permanent damage.
Spinal instability that places spinal cord at risk.

valueCoding.code: Rapid worsening of symptoms specific to compression of nerve and/or spinal cord.
valueCoding.display: Rapid worsening of symptoms specific to compression of nerve and/or spinal cord.

item.text: Medical Coding & Procedure Details

The diagnosis that supports anterior cervical fusion for decompression of symptomatic cervical nerve root impingement. Provider note: Imaging (MRI or CT) or physician interpretation must be present and supports central, lateral recess or foraminal stenosis at corresponding level with clinical signs and symptoms and including at least of the following

valueCoding.display: Symptomatic Cervical Nerve Root Impingement
Symptomatic Cervical Canal Stenosis

valueCoding.display: Decompression or stabilization of the cervical spine

item.text: Documentation supports that all other sources of pain have been excluded. Provider Note:  Non-Qualifying Conditions for for Cervical Fusion with Disc Removal include but are limited to:  The following medical conditions are not appropriate indicators for this procedure and must be ruled out: Isolated Chronic Axial Cervical Neck Pain, Thoracic Outlet Syndrome, Brachial Plexopathy, Peripheral Nerve Compression, Peripheral Neuropathy, Rotator Cuff Impingement, and Myofascial pain.

valueCoding.display: N/A
Yes, all other sources have been ruled out, including but not limited to e.g., thoracic outlet syndrome, isolated chronic axial cervical pain, and peripheral neuropathy.
No

item.text: Documentation supports that all other sources of pain/neurological deficits have been excluded. Provider Note:  Non-Qualifying Conditions for Cervical Fusion with Disc Removal:  The following medical conditions are not appropriate indications for this procedure and must be ruled out:  Isolated Axial Neck Pain, Facet Joint Syndrome, Cervical Muscle Strain, Myofascial Pain Syndrome, Cardiac Ischemia, Spinal Epidural Abscess or Vertebral Osteomyelitis, Infections affecting the spine, or Primary or Metastatic Spinal Tumors

item.text: Imaging Results or Physician Interpretation
Evidence of relevant symptoms?
Encounter Date

Persistent or recurrent moderate or severe arm pain (4 or more on the visual analog scale or equivalent) present for a minimum of 12 weeks within the current episode of pain with documented failure to respond to multimodal conservative management (as tolerated) in the absence of exceptional circumstances.

valueCoding.display: None
Mild
Moderate
Severe

Radicular pain: Running from the neck, over the shoulder, lateral outer arm, to the thumb and index finger.
Radicular pain: Pain from the neck to the back of the shoulder back of the arm and into the middle finger.
